newsitem.title: CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Banqui opposition boycott government, call strike.
newsitem.headline: Banqui opposition boycott government, call strike.

text.p: Opposition parties suspended their role in the Central African Republic government on Monday and called for a general strike on Tuesday over the killing of three disaffected soldiers.
"The group of 11 opposition political parties holds President Ange-Felix Patasse responsible for the murder of the three ex-mutineers," a joint statement from the parties said.
The statement called on the public to stay home on Tuesday to protest against Friday's killings.

Three soldiers, who took part in army mutinees which erupted three times in little more than a year, were killed by security forces under circumstances which a government statement at the time did not make clear.
Independent sources allege the three were disarmed before they were killed by the paramilitary police.

The opposition parties, who called for an inquiry into the killings, have held eight of 27 government posts since February, as part of a deal to restore peace after the mutinies which began over pay but became a campaign to oust Patasse.

The first mutinies were in April and May 1996. The third, which began on November 15, degenerated into ethnic bloodshed. French troops, in the country under a defence pact, restored order and handed over to African peacekeepers.
The mutineers are principally from the southern Yakoma tribe of former military leader Andre Kolingba. Patasse is a northern civilian elected in 1993.
